Description:
Description of IPC Section 140
According to section 140 of Indian penal code, Whoever, not being a soldier, sailor or airman in the Military, Naval or Air service of the Government of India, wears any garb or carries any token resembling any garb or token used by such a soldier, sailor or airman with the intention that it may be believed that he is such a soldier, sailor or airman, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three months, or with fine which may extend to five hundred rupees, or with both.


IPC 140 in Simple Words
If someone who is not a military member wears a uniform or carries something resembling a military uniform to deceive others into believing they are a soldier, sailor, or airman, they can be punished with up to three months in jail, a fine of up to five hundred rupees, or both.
Offense: Wearing the dress or carrying any token used by a soldier, sailor or airman with intent that it may be believed that he is such a soldier, sailor or airman
Predicted Punishment:
If someone who is not a military member wears a uniform or carries anything resembling a military uniform to trick people into thinking that they’re a serviceman, they could get fined between Rs 500 and Rs 5,000 (or equivalent) or imprisoned for up to one year.

Explanation:
Section 144A provides that whoever makes an attempt on behalf of another person to commit an offence punishable under this Act commits an offence also if his act has been intended to facilitate commission thereof.

Description:
Description of IPC Section 127
According to section 127 of Indian penal code, Whoever receives any property knowing the same to have been taken in the commission of any of the offences mentioned in sections 125 and 126, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine and to forfeiture of the property so received.


IPC 127 in Simple Words
If someone receives property knowing it was taken during the commission of certain offenses (mentioned in sections 125 and 126), they can be punished with imprisonment of up to seven years, fined, and the property can be forfeited.
Offense: Receiving property taken by war or depredation mentioned in sections 125 And 126
Predicted Punishment: Whoever recieves any Property knowinbg that is has been takeen In Comission Of Any Offence Mentioned In Secion 125 Or 126 Shall Be Punished With Imprisonment For A Term Which May Extends To Seven Years & Shal Also Bly Layd Unto Fine

Description:
Description of IPC Section 128
According to section 128 of Indian penal code, Whoever, being a public servant and having the custody of any State prisoner or prisoner of war, voluntarily allows such prisoner to escape from any place in which such prisoner is confined, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.


IPC 128 in Simple Words
If a public servant, responsible for the custody of a State prisoner or prisoner of war, intentionally allows the prisoner to escape from confinement, they can be punished with life imprisonment or imprisonment of up to ten years, and may also be fined.
Offense: Public servant voluntarily allowing prisoner of State or war in his custody to escape
Actual Punishment: Imprisonment for Life or 10 Years + Fine
Predicted Punishment:
If a public servant (1) knowingly permits an escaped convict to re-enter India after escaping; or (2) knowingly aids another person who has been convicted by court-martial under this Act to commit an offence punishable under subsection (3); then he/she will face jail time as well as pay hefty fines.
Whoever commits offense under sub-section (4), if sentenced on conviction to death, shall suffer death;
In addition to that, whoever commits other offenses specified in clause(5), shall be punished accordingly:
(a)(i) With rigorous imprisonment for three months,
(ii) For every subsequent commission of like offences, with rigorous imprisonment for one month each.

Explanation : - The expression "like" includes similar cases but not identical ones

What are the Offences?
The following types of crimes fall within the scope of IPC Chapter-127 :
• Escape of Prisoner
• Aiding others to Commit Crimes against Society

Description:
Description of IPC Section 129
According to section 129 of Indian penal code, Whoever, being a public servant and having the custody of any State prisoner or prisoner of war, negligently suffers such prisoner to escape from any place of confinement in which such prisoner is confined, shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine.


IPC 129 in Simple Words
If a public servant, responsible for the custody of a State prisoner or prisoner of war, carelessly allows the prisoner to escape from confinement, they can be punished with up to three years in jail and may also be fined.
Offense: Public servant negligently suffering prisoner of State or war in his custody to escape
Predicted Punishment:
A person who commits this offense has been sentenced by courts to pay fines ranging between Rs.5000/-to Rs.1 lakh/-. The court will not impose more than one year's prison time on an individual if he/she committed the crime while acting under duress.

Explanation:
The offence relates specifically to negligence rather than intent; it does not matter whether the accused had maliciously intended that the state prisoners should escape (which would constitute culpable homicide).
A public servant cannot commit this offence merely because their failure was due to circumstances beyond their control - e.g., a fire broke out at a police station where many inmates were kept, causing some to flee. However, even then there must have been no wilful act done by them as well as other factors contributing towards the accident like inadequate security measures etc.

Description:
Description of IPC Section 130
According to section 130 of Indian penal code, Whoever knowingly aids or assists any State prisoner or prisoner of war in escaping from lawful custody, or rescues or attempts to rescue any such prisoner, or harbours or conceals any such prisoner who has escaped from lawful custody, or offers or attempts to offer any resistance to the recapture of such prisoner shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.


IPC 130 in Simple Words
If someone knowingly helps a State prisoner or prisoner of war escape from lawful custody, rescues them, hides them after their escape, or resists their recapture, they can be punished with life imprisonment or imprisonment of up to ten years, and may also be fined.
Offense: Aiding escape of, rescuing or harbouring, such prisoner, or offering Any resistance to the recapture of such prisoner
Actual Punishment: Imprisonment for Life or 10 Years + Fine
Predicted Punishment:
The offense is punishable by death (life), imprisonment of not less than seven nor more than fifteen years, and/or fine.

Explanation:
The word "knowingly" means that one knows what he/she does while doing something else; it implies an intent on his/her part to do so. In other words, if there was no intention then how would knowing help? So here we have two options-
1) If you are trying to aid another person in committing crime against law - i.e., aiding him/her to commit theft etc.; this offence will come under section 120B(2). This offence carries lesser penalty as compared to sections like 121A/122(A).
2) If you know about some event but don't take action due to lack of knowledge- e.g., you see somebody stealing your property without taking necessary precautions; in case of such offences where negligence plays role, the maximum punishment comes out to be imprisonment upto five years alongwith fine.

Example:

You witness robbery at night time when all people were asleep. You didn’t inform police immediately because you thought that nobody could catch them during dark hours.
In such cases, even though you knew

Description:
Description of IPC Section 131
According to section 131 of Indian penal code, Whoever abets the committing of mutiny by an officer, soldier, sailor or airman, in the Army, Navy or Air Force of the Government of India or attempts to seduce any such officer, soldier, sailor or airman from his allegiance or his duty, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.


IPC 131 in Simple Words
If someone encourages the commission of mutiny by an officer, soldier, sailor, or airman in the Indian Army, Navy, or Air Force or tries to lead them astray from their loyalty or duty, they can be punished with life imprisonment or imprisonment of up to ten years, and may also be fined.
Offense: Abetting mutiny, or attempting to seduce an officer, soldier sailor or airman from his allegiance or duty
Actual Punishment: Imprisonment for Life or 10 Years + Fine
Predicted Punishment:
If anyone commits the crime of aiding or encouraging mutineers (officers) then he will have to serve at least one year's rigorous imprisonment and pay a penalty of Rs.10 thousand.

## Question

What is meant by "mutinous"?

Explanation:

The word Mutinies means 'to rebel against' or 'a rebellion'. A person who rebels against authority is known as a Muttie. In this context it refers to those soldiers who revolted against British rule during the First War of Independence.

Description:
Description of IPC Section 132
According to section 132 of Indian penal code, Whoever abets the committing of mutiny by an officer, soldier, sailor or airman, in the Army, Navy or Air Force of the Government of India, shall, if mutiny be committed in consequence of that abetment, be punished with death or with imprisonment for life, or imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.


IPC 132 in Simple Words
If someone encourages the commission of mutiny by an officer, soldier, sailor, or airman in the Indian Army, Navy, or Air Force, and mutiny occurs as a result, the abettor can be punished with death, life imprisonment, or imprisonment for up to ten years, and may also be fined.
Offense: Abetment of mutiny, if mutiny is committed in consequence thereof
Actual Punishment: Death or Imprisonment for Life or 10 Years + Fine
Predicted Punishment:
If anyone encourages the commission of mutiny by an officer, soldier, sailor, or airman (an "abettor"), he/she will face severe punishments such as death, prison time ranging from five to twenty-five years, fines, etc., depending on whether it was done intentionally or unintentionally.

Section Number: 132

Sub-Sections:

1) Whoever abets the committing of mutiny by an officer, soldier, sailor or airman, in the army, navy or air force of the government of india,shall,if mutinybecommittedinconsequenceofthatabetmentation,punishablewithdeath.orimprisonforlife,andshallalsobelyaileftfine

Description:
Description of IPC Section 133
According to section 133 of Indian penal code, Whoever abets an assault by an officer, soldier, sailor or airman, in the Army, Navy or Air Force of the Government of India, on any superior officer being in the execution of his office, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine.


IPC 133 in Simple Words
If someone encourages an officer, soldier, sailor, or airman to assault a superior officer while the superior officer is performing their duties, the abettor can be punished with up to three years in jail and a fine.
Offense: Abetment of an assault by An officer, soldier, sailor Or airman on his superior officer, when in the execution of his office
Predicted Punishment:
The offender who encouraged another person to commit crime will face prison time from one year to ten years along with fines.

Explanation:
The offense under this provision occurs if you encourage anyone else (such as your friend) to attack a higher-ranking official during that individual’s performance of duty. If they are injured because of such encouragement, then you could potentially go to court facing charges of “abetting” them into committing crimes against authority figures like police officers, judges, military officials, etc., even though it was not directly done at work.

For example:

Suppose two men were discussing how much fun it would be to rob some bank tellers after hours; however, one man suggested going undercover so he wouldn’t get caught doing anything illegal since there wasn't enough evidence yet proving him guilty anyway! This type of behavior falls within what's called "abetting" - meaning helping others break laws without actually participating yourself!

To prove guilt beyond reasonable doubt requires prosecutors presenting sufficient proof showing all elements present including intent & motive behind encouraging criminal conduct among those involved regardless whether these individuals acted upon suggestions given out loud verbally OR silently via social media posts online forums where people discuss breaking rules set forth legally governing society today...

This means courts must decide exactly WHAT actions did occur leading up towards creating consequences resulting FROM THESE CONDUCTS THAT COULD

Description:
Description of IPC Section 134
According to section 134 of Indian penal code, Whoever abets an assault by an officer, soldier, sailor or airman, in the Army, Navy or Air Force of the Government of India, on any superior officer being in the execution of his office, shall, if such assault be committed in consequence of that abetment be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.


IPC 134 in Simple Words
If someone encourages an officer, soldier, sailor, or airman to assault a superior officer while the superior officer is performing their duties, and the assault occurs as a result, the abettor can be punished with up to seven years in jail and a fine.
Offense: Abetment of such assault, if the assault is committed
Predicted Punishment:
If someone encourages another person (officer) who has been appointed under Article 370(1)(a), i.e., he/she belongs to J&K state; then it will become punishable offence under this provision.

Explanation:
This article provides punishments when one encourages others to commit offences against other officers belonging to the same category. This means they are encouraged to do something illegal but not necessarily violent like murder, rape etc. The crime must have taken place because of encouragement from them.

Description:
Description of IPC Section 135
According to section 135 of Indian penal code, Whoever, abets the desertion of any officer, soldier, sailor or airman, in the Army, Navy or Air Force of the Government of India, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.


IPC 135 in Simple Words
If someone encourages or supports the desertion of an officer, soldier, sailor, or airman from the Indian Army, Navy, or Air Force, they can be punished with up to two years in jail, a fine, or both.
Offense: Abetment of the desertion of an officer, soldier, sailor or airman
Predicted Punishment:
Punishment is not given if there are no other punishments specified.

Section Number and Name: IPC - Penal Code
